Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Systems Approach for Identification and Evaluation of Nanoscience and Nanomanufacturing Opportunities and Risks

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the National Nanotechnology Initiative (NNI) was announced in 2000, significant progress has been made in understanding the unique physical phenomena that occur at the nano-scale and in designing and making new nano-scale materials, structures and devices. To realize the benefits of nanotechnology, research efforts have increased in the area of nanomanufacturing, which is the pathway to commercialization. Large-scale manufacturing of nano-enabled products brings opportunities and challenges. This project will conduct a systematic study of nanotechnology and nanomanufacturing and identify and evaluate opportunities for research and risks associated with production of large quantities of nanomaterials. A systems approach to collect and analyze bibliographic and patent data will be used. The project will examine new methods of gathering the information and study new models to assess it. It will identify emerging topics and sub-topics and identify the environmental, health and safety (EHS) risks during the manufacture and use of nanomaterials. The results of this study will guide the government and researchers in determining what research gaps exist and how their resources and investments could be directed to address important areas in nanotechnology.

The objective of this EArly Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to develop new analytical models and frameworks to analyze the outputs of research and innovation nanotechnology and nanomanufacturing. Nanotechnology publication and patent data records from ISI Web of Science and US Patent and Trade Office (USPTO) will be mined. The project will employ topic modeling and clustering, trend analysis, and visualization techniques to develop a monitoring system that will classify and characterize a vast array of nanotechnology topics and subtopics, track their evolution, and identify emerging areas of research. In addition, various text mining techniques will be used to extract and analyze EHS data associated with nanomanufacturing processes and large-scale nanomaterial production. Appropriate social media, books, magazines and journal articles will be the sources for this analysis. Since nanotechnology is a rapidly developing field tracking it has to be at a much faster pace than before. In the new framework, nanotechnology domain knowledge in topic modeling will be incorporated and the topics updated dynamically in shorter time intervals. This is a challenge because it requires collecting denser data in a short period of time. Also, the project is a first attempt to include wider public participation in identifying EHS risks of nanotechnology. Conventional risk evaluation approach is based on expert knowledge in certain subfields. The new approach will incorporate the perspectives and knowledge of various stakeholders, including researchers, inventors, opinion leaders, and end-users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop improved frameworks for analyzing the development opportunities and Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS) risks in nanoscience and nanomanufacturing. In order to do this, we conducted two streams of research within the project.

The first research stream analyzed global nanotechnology development from 2000 to 2016 in order to identify the opportunities by contrasting the developments in the “Nano1” (2000-2010) and “Nano2” (2011-present) time frames. Grants, scientific papers, and patent publications were used as metrics for comparing five international nanotechnology R&D leaders’ nanotechnology development performance (i.e., U.S., EU, Japan, and China).

NSF funding opportunities for nanotechnology are increasing in the Nano2 era and vast amounts of investment will likely be spent on nanotechnology in order to stimulate its development. In terms of scientific paper publications, nanotechnology researchers in the U.S. and EU dominate the nano-related papers in the top three journals (Nature, Science, Proceedings of National Academy of Science (PNAS)). New nanotechnology identified in Nano2 (e.g., “graphene,” ”synthetic biology,” and “DNA assembling”) are the topics of 11-15% of nano-related papers. This finding suggests that the U.S. and EU are leading the exploration of more application-driven fundamental research as well as integrative nanosystems research. After getting a late start in the field, the number of China’s nano-related papers published in the International Science Indexing (ISI) journals significantly surpass those of other countries or regions. Through this extensive publication effort, China is playing an active role and catching up with latest nanotechnology research opportunities.

Nano-related patent publications had similar patterns as compared with scientific publications.  Inventors in the U.S. dominated novel nanotechnology patents in the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO), and Chinese inventors focused more on patent applications in traditional nanotechnology domains across worldwide patent offices. The U.S. is still the dominant player regarding the number of patents in USPTO and the number of publications in the top three journals, but its shares are decreasing. China is experiencing significant growth in the number of patents in worldwide patent depositories and the number of publications in all ISI journals.

With competition in the global nanotechnology market increasing, however, it was interesting to note that the speed of nanotechnology development slowed down in Nano2. This finding suggests that researchers faced challenges developing more complex, application-driven nanosystems. More investment and joint research efforts are likely needed to ensure nanotechnology’s steady growth into the future.

In the second research stream, we developed a systematic approach for understanding public opinion towards Nano-EHS risks on social media platforms (e.g., Twitter). We identified 11 Nano-EHS subtopics, analyzed the trend, polarity proportions of different subtopics, and examined events that affected public perceptions.

On social media platform (e.g., Twitter), #Nanotechnology and #nanotech are the most commonly mentioned hashtags followed by #Quantum. The most frequently mentioned company entity is IBM, which has been researching quantum computing for years. These findings indicate that the public tends to discuss more general nanotechnology and quantum-related technology breakthroughs.

We used topic modeling to extract 11 underlying subtopics and their associated keywords from the nano-EHS related online news articles. The subtopics included Energy (solar power and photovoltaic systems), Nanometer Precision (nano-motor and piezoelectric materials), Quantum (quantum operations and quantum computing), Microfluidics, Semiconductor, Optical Lithography, Health and Safety, Microscope, Commercialization, Material (nanoparticles and membranes), and Bio (genome, nanomedicine and therapy). Our collected nano-related tweets were then classified into these subtopics for further analysis.

The majority (58.1%) of tweets were objective, and only shared information about nanotechnology. Besides the Neutral tweets, the public showed a more positive (27.3%) attitude toward nano-EHS topics than negative opinions (13.0%) on Twitter. In “Health and Safety” and “Bio” subtopics, the public expressed more opinions that are non-neutral (83% and 74%) since these subtopics are less technical and closer to our daily lives. We further analyzed the term frequencies within these two subtopics. In “Health and Safety” subtopics, “live cell,” “#healthinnovations,” and “wearable digital devices” were the apopular focuses. Such a pervasive positive attitude showed the public’s optimistic expectation towards nanotechnology’s application in the health domain.

With our developed opinion mining framework, we also conducted temporal analyses to understand the opinion trend of nano-EHS related topics. We were able to recognize events that significantly influenced the opinions (e.g., tweets introducing the positive features of Synthetic Biology, tweets discussing the negative consequence of Brexit on material science funding opportunities). With our developed framework, we can monitor the trend of public opinions on social media platforms. Significant events, key opinion leaders, and heated-discussed topics that shape public perspectives about nanotechnology can be identified with our framework.
